reviewText:
Polyology is a simple little puzzle game in which you push blocks around, to join each other in the least number of possible moves.
The puzzles get harder as you level up.
A good game to exercise your mind.
It has a fun little avatar, so that's all good.
Although the design may look simple, don't be fooled - as many of the puzzles are definitely not simple.
A good game for some puzzle fun.
Go on and try it.

P.S. It looks like this is the first review of this game on Steam.
Nice one. Where's my prize? :-)
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Having completed 37.8% of the game in 20 minutes I think I am ready to review it.
If you can see the screenshots you know this isn't a game that will stand on its graphics, though the movement and animation do look very smooth.
When I play a simple puzzle game like this what I look for is unique elements.
Thoug Sliding blocks around isn't new, each set of stages adds a new type of block that changes the rules just enough to keep things interesting.
If you can watch the trailer and think it looks like your kind of game, buy it.
It plays well, challenging but not too difficult, controls smoothly, the music is good, and there are achievements to go for too.
Definitely worth grabbing on the next sale for any puzzler fan.

reviewText:
Polyology is an outstanding little puzzle game and is Gridlock Interactive’s Steam debut title.  Unfortunately, however, it appears to have been sadly ignored in the Steam catalog since it was released about a week ago. The game deserves much more attention by puzzle fans as there is much to enjoy about the game. Besides, if the cute soundtrack doesn’t put a smile on your face I’m not certain what will.

But besides the soundtrack, the Steam description below saves me the trouble of explaining it to you but read it please, the overall presentation of the game has been really well done. I’m an unabashed numbers guy. I’ve followed statistics and my entire life. It started out with trying to understand all of the different numbers and statistics in all of the various sports that I enjoy and then sprouted from there. To see a puzzle game that is strictly about numbers and sorting the pattern out to get to them is my jam. What makes it even better is when there are a number of different mechanics featured in the game such as sliding and switching the blocks. It makes you concentrate so much more especially when you know that each puzzle has been immaculately designed with a real solution that makes you put your thinking cap on.

I’m not going to tell you that the game is perfect. Ideally I’d love to have seen a level editor included with the game so that people could make their own levels up. This is the perfect game where I would have loved to have been able to make challenges for Ainslie to solve only for her to create even more difficult levels to try and get me back. Then we’d love to share our lovely levels with you gorgeous people on the Steam store. But if the lack of a level editor is my biggest gripe about the game itself, and it is, then I have to believe that the game is doing alright for itself. The other issue is the price. I’m not quite sold on it being a $4.99 game. It seems a dollar or two too high but I can appreciate why the price point is set there. If there were a little bit more to the game (such as that level editor) I’d be happy to really recommend it but at this price perhaps its best for a sale unless you’re like me and really love your number puzzle games. I think the price may be keeping players at bay.

I hope that the sales and Steam reviews for the game pick up. It’s a very cleverly designed game with good production values.
